2020459.eventHeadline: Honeywell International Inc., 2016 Guidance/Update Call, Dec 16, 2015
2020459.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Alicia. Good morning, and welcome to Honeywell's 2016 outlook conference call. With me here today is Senior Vice President and CFO, Tom Szlosek. This call and webcast, including any non-GAAP reconciliations, are available on our website at www.honeywell.com/investor. Note that elements of this presentation contain forward-looking statements that are based on our best view of the world and of our businesses as we see them today. Those elements can change, and we ask that you interpret them in that light. We identify the principal risks and uncertainties that affect our performance in our Form 10-K and other SEC filings. This morning, we will review our financial expectations for the remainder of 2015 and discuss our 2016 planning, building on the framework we gave you back in October. Finally, as always, we'll leave time for your questions at the end. 
So with that, I will turn the call over to Tom.

---

Okay, thanks, Mark, and good morning everyone. Let's begin on Slide 3 by confirming that our fourth quarter earnings guidance is on track, while core organic sales are coming in slightly lower than we guided. The sales outlook for Aerospace remains in line, but we're experiencing lower volumes in ACS and continued weakness in PMT as a result of lower conversion of the backlog. The good news is that we continue to expect strong segment margin and earnings performance in the quarter, and we are reaffirming our guidance of approximately $1.58 per share before any pension mark-to-market adjustments, so up 10% year-on-year. And based on the current interest rates and year-to-date asset returns in our pension fund, we expect a minimal mark-to-market adjustment in our U.S. pension plans. Free cash flow in the quarter, approximately $1.4 billion, reflecting conversion of 115%, and building on our strong cash performance in the second half of the year. For the full year, we're expecting core organic sales to be up approximately 1% to $38.5 billion. The execution across our portfolio has allowed us to drive continuous margin expansion, and we anticipate closing the year up approximately 220 basis points to 18.8% or 180 basis points, excluding the fourth quarter 2014 OEM incentives. Our strong segment margin performance and continued cost management will drive another year of double-digit earnings growth, up approximately 10% year-on-year to an estimated $6.10 before the pension mark-to-market adjustment. We're expecting free cash flow of $4.2 billion to $4.3 billion, so up 8% to 10% versus 2014, as we benefit from higher net income and an improvement in working capital. This represents full year conversion of approximately 88%, which includes an elevated level of CapEx at a reinvestment ratio of roughly 165%. So we remain confident in our ability to execute on the earnings guidance we set last December, continuing our track record of delivering strong performance in an even more challenging environment. 
Moving to Slide 4. There are number of other important accomplishments for 2015 that don't make it into the core financial numbers, and I want to take a moment to recap some of them. For starters, the upgrades we made to our M&A organization and processes are bearing fruit across the entire portfolio. We announced 5 acquisitions in 4 months and will deploy around $5.5 billion in capital when the transactions close. We're very excited about the software and satellite communication offerings of COM DEV, Satcom 1 and Aviaso. The broad product portfolio that Sigma Aldrich offers -- or adds to our Fine Chemicals business, and the differentiated technologies that Elster will bring to our ACS and PMT portfolios. We also continue to invest in organic growth with over $1 billion in capital expenditures, which is driving above-market growth in the portfolio, particularly in UOP's catalysts business and in Fluorine Products. We maintained our R&D spend at approximately 5% of sales. That's 7% including the customer-funded R&D in our Aerospace business. Last week, we announced that 100% of our global software divisions are compatible with CMMI or Capability Maturity Model Integration Level 5. CMMI maturity Level 5 is the pinnacle of software development excellence and improves software quality, user experience and predictability of schedule and cost. More than half of our 22,000 engineers globally are focused on software development. And as we continue to rollout HOS Gold, we're identifying and funding restructuring projects with attractive paybacks. We expect to invest over $130 million in new restructuring projects this year alone, and expect to see $150 million to $175 million in 2016 benefits. After a 15% increase in 2014, we again increased our annual dividend rate by 15% in 2015, representing the 11th increase in the past 10 years, reflecting our commitment to grow the dividend faster than our earnings growth. And we repurchased almost $2 billion in Honeywell stock or about 2.5% of our market cap, lowering our weighted average share count for the full year to 789 million shares. All-in for 2015, we're deploying approximately $10 billion in capital through CapEx, dividend, M&A and share repurchases or roughly 2.5x the amount we deployed in 2014. So in addition to the strong operational performance, an exciting year for Honeywell in terms of putting our capital to work, and we still have significant balance sheet firepower as we head into 2016. 
Let's turn to Slide 5 to provide a little more color around the surge in M&A activity we experienced in the second half of 2015. It's been a good year for Honeywell's M&A. Under Roger Fradin and Anne Madden's leadership, we've reinforced our global M&A team and are looking at broader spaces and adjacencies in our businesses. What hasn't changed is our disciplined M&A approach and our rigorous financial framework. We continue to focus on Great Positions in Good Industries. The businesses we acquired this year align well to key growth themes, including connectivity, energy efficiency and differentiated technology. Our ability to integrate and execute on our synergy plans will continue to drive attractive returns for our shareholders. Since July, we've announced approximately $5.5 billion in acquisitions. In Aerospace, we continued our investments in connectivity with the acquisitions of COM DEV 1 and Satcom 1. COM DEV, a leader in the satellite components market, positions us well as the demand for higher bandwidth drives the need for more components for satellite. Satcom 1 enables us to offer an end-to-end solution for in-flight connectivity, from hardware to airtime and service. We also acquired Aviaso, which bolsters our software offerings to our airline customers to drive fuel savings. In PMT, we're acquiring Sigma Aldrich's research chemicals business, which strengthens our portfolio of high purity research chemicals, adding industry-leading brands to our well-established Fine Chemicals business. And of course, we're looking forward to the Elster close, and making progress on all fronts in that regard working through the antitrust clearance processes and staffing our integration teams. Elster boasts a leading portfolio in gas heating, controls, metering and advanced technologies, and we're confident that our deployment of HOS Gold to the operations of Elster will drive enhanced global growth and attractive cost synergies. We'll provide further color on the integration and plans for growth at our 2016 Investor Day on March 2. Even with a banner year for M&A nearly behind us, there are no signs of slowdown and our pipeline of potential targets is robust. 
Let's turn to Slide 6. As we close out 2015, it's also worth reminding everyone of the long-term targets we set in 2014 and how we performed so far against those targets. Now from a top line perspective, it's no revelation that our key end markets have been slower than anticipated, particularly in our energy-related businesses. But we have generated decent growth in certain businesses including Fluorine Products, Transportation Systems and in our high-growth regions. We are far outpacing our 5-year plan of 45 to 75 basis points per year of margin expansion, with improvements across all the businesses. We expect that the permanent improvements to our factories, footprint and supply chain through the deployment of HOS Gold will continue to drive margin expansion over the course of the plan and beyond. From an earnings perspective, the higher margin expansion has more than offset the impact of lower sales, and 2015 should mark our sixth consecutive year of double-digit earnings per share growth. With this performance, our EPS growth was beat -- in the median of our peer group in each of the last 5 years, and we've done it without using our capital to reduce share count. So we've preserved the firepower that we're now putting to work to enhance shareowner returns. 
I'm on Slide 7 highlighting how we're thinking about our end markets for 2016. Before I touch on the individual verticals here, I want to point out that our diverse portfolio with its mix of short- and long-cycle businesses that span the globe, provides our shareowners with broad vertical exposure. So for example, while our heritage is B2B, our businesses do have good exposure to consumer, such as through our aero aftermarket, turbocharger and HVAC businesses. And we're aligned to enduring macro trends, that is energy efficiency, clean energy generation, safety and security, urbanization and customer productivity, which means that we can grow even in slower environments. So on balance, we expect a slower growth environment to persist in 2016. In nonresidential construction, we expect demand to remain stable. The Commercial Aftermarket industry will continue to grow, albeit at a slower pace as flight hours for air transport and regional are expected to be up 3.5% to 4.5% and for large cabin business jets up 4% to 5% in 2016. But increased airline efficiency and the retirement of older aircraft will temper demand. Defense & Space will be neutral with strong international demand, while U.S. DoD budgets begin to grow. Oil and gas, which represents only 11% of the Honeywell portfolio, will continue to experience headwinds in 2016 as customers aggressively manage their OpEx and CapEx budgets and delay investment decisions as a result of lower oil prices. In vehicles, global auto production has been robust, with good demand for passenger vehicles in the U.S., Europe and China. In addition, global turbo adoption continues to accelerate and we expect global penetration of diesel and gas turbocharger technology in roughly half of all vehicles on the road by 2020. We continue to monitor the Volkswagen emissions matter very closely for implications to our business. Sales to VW represent less than 1% of total Honeywell sales and we are well-positioned from our 40%-plus win rate to benefit from any market shifts. Turbocharging will continue to be a compelling technology to enable OEMs to meet fuel efficiency and emission standards, while enhancing engine performance. On the OE side of Commercial Aero, our air transport customers have healthy backlogs, with a ramp in production that -- expected across several platforms, while business jet growth overall will be lower. For the rest of our key end markets, we're expecting a slight improvement as customers continue to demand products that are safer, more secure and energy-efficient. Our planning philosophy for 2016 is similar to what's worked for the last couple of years. We'll be cautious in our sales planning, while investing to support long-term growth in new products and technologies, including UOP Catalysts and Fluorine Products, as well as further penetration in high-growth regions. But it also means continuing to plan conservatively in terms of our cost structure. So in addition to the ongoing productivity initiatives in our supply chain and function through -- HOS Gold, we're prepared to leverage the flexibility we have to quickly adjust cost levels as the need arises. 
So with that, I'll turn to Slide 8 to talk through our guidance for 2016. We expect core organic sales growth of 1% to 2% for the next year. Reported sales growth will be higher, in the range of 4% to 6%, primarily due to the favorable impact of M&A. We expect Elster to close earlier than anticipated as we're making good progress on the regulatory approvals. Of course, this will not impact our core organic sales rate for the full year. The stronger dollar will be a roughly 1% to 2% headwind to reported sales growth. Segment margins expected to be 18.9% to 19.3%. That's up 10 to 50 basis points on a reported basis, 80 to 110 basis points excluding M&A. Our continued deployment of HOS Gold and key process initiatives will drive further productivity improvements. We also will benefit significantly from executing on the approximate $300 million pool of funded restructuring projects. 
EPS excluding pension mark-to-market is expected to be $6.45 to $6.70. So up 6% to 10% assuming a tax rate of approximately 26.5% and share count roughly flat to 2015 full year average. We've discussed previously the FX headwind we're facing in 2016. Our largest exposure remains the euro, which we've hedged roughly 85% of at a rate of approximately $1.10 versus approximately $1.24 in 2015. So FX will be a headwind of roughly $0.15 per share in 2016. For the below the line items, the only significant change in 2016 is our November 15 move from a single weighted average discount rate approach for accruing the interest component of pension expense to the alternative spot rate approach. This will reduce our service and interest cost in 2016 on all plans. As a result, our 2016 pension income will be approximately $125 million higher than 2015 and approximately $25 million higher in the fourth quarter of 2015 than previously guided. We will offset this incremental pension income with funding of new restructuring projects, which in turn will drive further productivity and margin enhancement. 
On cash flow, we expect to generate between $4.6 billion and $4.8 billion free cash flow or an increase of 8% to 13%. CapEx investments will be roughly flat to 2015. Free cash flow conversion is expected to be approximately 90% and we expect to achieve a 100% conversion run rate by the end of 2017, driven by a more normalized rate of CapEx, increasing net income and continued working capital improvements. 
Now on Slide 9 to provide more specifics on the 2016 sales plan. We're exiting 2015 at a slower growth rates than we had anticipated at this time last year, in large part due to the market headwinds we faced in our oil and gas businesses. We are planning for a roughly 1% decline associated with these businesses in 2016. Also, for prudency, our planning includes an approximate 1% sales contingency covering approximately 2/3 of our portfolio. For the other 1/3 of the portfolio, we have good visibility to above average growth rates based on orders in backlog, improving end market trends and new wins. For example, we expect good growth in our Solstice products and advanced materials, in transportation systems, in our short-cycle commercial and residential products businesses and in our high-growth regions. All told, these factors should contribute 3% to 4% of growth. We've built a credible and attainable plan predicated on cautious sales planning, conservatism on cost and focused execution. However, if sales trended to the lower end of our range or worse, we are prepared with contingency restructuring capacity and the flexibility to make quick adjustments to our cost structure as necessary to protect our earnings commitment. 
Moving to M&A. The 5% to 6% impact represents the additions of Elster, COM DEV, Sigma Aldrich's Fine Chemicals business, Satcom 1 and Aviaso to our portfolio. The positive M&A impact is offset in part by the top line headwind from FX. From a sales perspective, we're conservatively planning the euro at approximately $1 for all of 2016 versus an average of approximately $1.11 in 2015. We expect total reported sales growth to be 4% to 6% in 2016 as a result. 
Let's move to Slide 10. Our margin performance has stood out, but it's not coming at the expense of future growth. Reinvesting in our businesses both organically and inorganically is an imperative for the Honeywell leadership team. Every initiative you see on this page reflects this priority. For example, with HOS Gold, we're driving breakthrough initiatives, which are smart bets to create new technologies and new markets to outperform our peers. HOS Gold also creates operating efficiency, which begets further restructuring opportunity, and we expect to see a minimum of $150 million in restructuring benefit in 2016. 
Let me move to Slide 11, the segment margin drivers. We're always being probed on segment margins in the businesses. What inning are we in? How much juice is in the lemon? Aren't you already at your long-term targets, and so forth. To give you an idea, to date there are approximately 50 ISC plants in our portfolio that are in full-scale HOS deployment, but are not even yet at bronze status. And an additional 85 plants that have not yet reached silver certification. Another example of the opportunity would be the recent portfolio alignments. While announced, we barely scratched the surface on the commercial and productivity improvements we will obtain from the realignment of the ACS portfolio as an example. And in Aerospace, you heard us talk about how inefficient and slow the industry is. Tim and his team are just getting ramped up at making our own aero supply chain more efficient. And we're already starting to see improvement where it matters most: on-time delivery to our customers. There are plenty of examples where we can improve our operations and cost structure, and thereby expand segment margin even in a slow-growth environment. And there are also plenty of levers to do so. The Honeywell User Experience is driving new products at higher margins. Our factories and sourcing organizations continue to mature under HOS Gold. We're leveraging the favorable commodities-driven sourcing environment. We continue to re-engineer our products to make them easier and less expensive to manufacture. Our functional transformation has been reinvigorated to improve the quality of our back-office while reducing its cost. And we continue to manage our indirect spend stringently. With these drivers in mind, we see 2016 as another year of meaningful margin expansion for Honeywell. Excluding the dilutive impact of the announced acquisitions, we expect margin will expand in a range of 80 to 110 basis points above the long-term targets of 45 to 75 basis points per year we originally set in 2014. On a reported basis, the margins are expected to expand 10 to 50 basis points, reflecting the year one dilutive impacts of M&A. 
I'm now on Slide 12, which bridges our 2015 earnings per share to that of 2016. We have a credible path to the EPS guidance for '16. Most of the EPS growth comes from the business segments through commercial excellence, new product introductions, continued productivity and the savings from prior period restructuring. In addition, the announced M&A deals, depending on the timing of their closing, will drive between $0.05 and $0.15 of earnings per share growth in 2016. On a run-rate basis, excluding onetime M&A costs and amortization, Elster is expected to eventually provide approximately $0.40 to $0.50 of EPS within a couple of years once the business is integrated and the synergies are achieved. I've discussed the 2016 FX headwind. Items below segment margin, including pension income and restructuring, are expected to be net flat and our tax rate is expected to remain at 26.5%. Of course, there will be puts and takes across the portfolio over the course of 2016, but our focus on growth where we can get it, conservative sales planning, continued productivity and balance sheet capacity give us the confidence that we built a credible plan. 
Let's turn to the strategic business units for some additional color. I'm on Slide 13, with the Aerospace outlook. Starting with the industry drivers on the left, flight hours are expected to grow at a similar pace in '16 as in '15. On the business jet side, the large cabin flight hours reflect continued demand in the cabin size sector where we have the most strength. Defense spending is expected to grow, particularly in the U.S , and should also continue to grow internationally given continuing global and regional tensions. We expect a modest pickup in vehicle production globally, while turbo penetration is expected to accelerate on light vehicle gas applications, particularly in the U.S. and China where we see healthy adoption rates. For aero, sales are expected in the range of $15.3 billion to $15.6 billion, up 1% to 2% on a reported and core organic basis with a 1 point benefit from M&A, offset by a 1 point headwind from foreign exchange. In Commercial OE, we're expecting core organic sales to be down mid-single-digit overall, driven by an increase in OEM incentives year-over-year. We have won significant content in the air transport and business aviation sectors, and this pickup in incentives reflects the ongoing cost of developing and growing our installed base in this industry. These incentives can vary from year-to-year and are fully incorporated into all of our planning, including the 2018 targets we shared with you in 2014. We point these incentives out when they create significant variation as we did in last year's fourth quarter. And depending on their nature, the incentives are treated as a reduction of revenue or as a cost. Either way, they reduce segment profit when incurred. This is in contrast to others in the industry who capitalize these costs on the balance sheet and gradually amortize them as a charge to earnings over future periods. We believe that our approach gives the greatest transparency to these incentives and avoid the unnecessary burden on future profits that comes with balance sheet capitalization. Now excluding the impact of the 2016 OEM incentives, Commercial OE sales are expected to increase low single digit. We're planning for low single-digit growth in BGA following a terrific year of double-digit growth in 2015, driven by strong engine shipments. We have very strong positions, but the BGA OE environment is softer. We're expecting improvement in ATR OE, with a ramp-up of key platforms like the Airbus A350 and A320 and the Boeing 737 and 787. Our Commercial Aftermarket business is expected to grow low single-digit again in 2016, with more volumes in airline repair and overhaul activity and higher maintenance events in BGA. On the spare side, we expect growth in line with flight hours. In Defense & Space, we're encouraged by the continued wins on the international side as well as the expected growth in our U.S. DoD business. In Transportation Systems, we expect to maintain our 40% plus win rate in competitions in 2015, which will help the business grow mid- or low to mid-single digits in 2016. However, commercial vehicles, which represent only about 15% of TS portfolio, continue to face headwinds from a downmarket. Aerospace segment margin is expected to be up 60 to 100 basis points or 80 to 120 basis points, excluding the impact of M&A, with contributions from both the legacy aerospace business and Transportation Systems. This business is doing it through the deployment of our T&A [ph] orders, with a particular focus on supply chain productivity, continued cost discipline and driving further efficiency across the segment. 
I'm now on Slide 14 with the ACS outlook. On the left, we have split the segment into the main verticals: residential, commercial and industrial. And as you can see, we're expecting a similar macro environment in '16, with improving residential construction growth, slow industrial production and moderating growth in commercial spending. Parts of our ACS portfolio, for example, industrial safety and sensing and productivity solutions, are driven by a variety of factors other than those indicated here, including spend by utilities, retailers and governments. We're expecting ACS core organic sales to be up 1% to 2% or 9% to 12% on a reported basis, with the difference primarily driven by the Elster acquisition. In ESS, we expect new product introductions and continued high-growth region penetration to drive the growth in 2016. Acceleration will come from our energy efficiency and connected products and technologies, along with continued growth in our Security and Fire business. After 4 straight quarters of double-digit growth, SNPS will see difficult comps beginning in the fourth quarter of 2015 as we lap the benefits of the U.S. Postal Service win. Our ACS China business unit will continue to grow strongly, driven by our One ACS China business strategy, localized business decision making and new product development, as well as continued penetration of Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities. We've also maintained our investments, adding resources in sales, marketing and engineering locally to drive further growth in China. On the industrial side, we expect continued headwinds in industrial safety driven by the oil and gas softness. In BSD, we're expecting improvement in Building Solutions driven by backlog and service bank conversion, while the Americas Distribution business should continue its strong top line growth. ACS segment margins expected to grow between 110 and 140 basis points, excluding the impact from M&A. So a continuation of the good margin expansion we saw in '15. The connected ACS initiative is driving results as we continue to identify and implement opportunities to leverage our scale in the supply chain, R&D, marketing and back office. As expected, Elster will be dilutive to ACS segment margin in 2016. The healthy margins underlying this acquisition will be offset by the typical first year impacts from purchase accounting and integration costs. To be clear, this was reflected in the deal model, which continues to meet our return expectations, including greater than 10% ROI in year 5. 
Moving to Slide 15 with the PMT outlook. You can see expectations for the key market drivers. After significant declines this year, we expect continued cuts in CapEx and minimal improvement in operating expenditures despite the easier comps. We expect the oil and gas environment will remain difficult with project delays, lower oil and gas rig counts, and as we've again experienced in the last few weeks, lower and more volatile oil prices. These conditions are likely to remain, and we've build our plans accordingly. PMT sales are expected to be $9.3 billion to $9.5 billion in 2016, a range of down 1% to up 1% on a core organic basis or up 1% to 4% reported, driven by the impacts of the Elster and Sigma Aldrich transactions. In UOP, as you're aware, the business comprises 4 primary revenue streams: technology licensing, engineering and services, equipment and catalysts. And for most of 2015, equipment orders were down in UOP, particularly in our U.S. midstream gas processing business, as well as in refining and petrochemicals. On the other hand, orders and sales for our catalyst products were robust throughout 2015. This quarter, we've continued to see growth in catalyst orders and as well an uptick in licensing, engineering and equipment orders, including for modular gas processing technology. As a result, total orders in UOP will be up significantly in the fourth quarter and will serve to keep our backlog, heading into 2016, down less than 10% from 2015 year-end levels. However, we are planning for generally slow conversion in this backlog and the possibility for continued deferral of investment decisions. With this backdrop, UOP 2016 sales are expected to be down mid-single-digits on a core organic basis. We expect continued demand for our catalyst technologies in both initial loads and reloads and the declines in our technology licensing and equipment businesses will moderate off an easier comparison. International orders for modular equipment in our gas processing business partially offset the softness we continue to experience in the U.S. In Process Solutions, with global megaprojects and reasonable stability in our service bank, we expect to enter 2016 with backlog up high single digit. Like UOP, the conversion of orders from HPS backlog has also been slower. However, we have seen some positive momentum recently on projects that were previously on hold. Our new product introductions, particularly in software and cybersecurity, along with improved win rates from joint HPS-UOP bids, will drive an improvement in 2016 sales growth rates for HPS. In Advanced Materials, sales are expected to increase mid-single digit on a core organic basis, driven by the ramp in Solstice product deliveries. This growth in Solstice technology is accelerating as we had anticipated and will be an even bigger driver to growth next year. We also expect improved volumes in Resins & Chemicals from better plant performance and an increase in specialty products volumes from new applications. PMT segment margins are expected to be up 30 to 60 basis points, excluding the impact of M&A. We expect to drive benefits from commercial excellence and continued productivity initiatives. PMT also continues to aggressively pursue further cost reduction opportunities, which should help further support margin expansion. 
Let me wrap up on Slide 16 before turning it back over to Mark for Q&A. In a couple of weeks, we'll complete another terrific year. We overcame significant macro headwinds and our businesses are executing well. We're finishing 2015 strongly with fourth quarter earnings tracking to our previous guidance, despite continued market slowness. We continue to deploy capital smartly, setting us up for further improvement and shareowner return. We've built a conservative and credible plan for 2016. Our growth assumptions are conservative, our productivity initiatives are working, and we have demonstrated the ability to perform in tough markets. We've also got a robust pipeline of funded restructuring, M&A tailwinds and a very healthy balance sheet. So while 2016 will be far from easy, we are confident that we'll once again perform well for our shareowners. 
So with that, Mark, let's move to Q&A.

---

Thank you, operator. If you can open up the line for questions.

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, well, I mean, I'd like to dispel that notion. When Dave does his reviews of AOP and STRAP, that's the first thing he's looking at is growth investments, whether it's in technology or high-growth regions, new products, that's his focus. We're basically not allowed to reduce and anywhere that there's headcount adds it is in R&D, sales and marketing, so the front end of the business. So if you look at it from a numerical perspective, we are still at that 7% of our sales that we've talked about. So that's not how we're doing it. To answer your question about what happens if we're at the lower end of our growth range, we think our guidance contemplates that with that 6% to 10%. We've also got some contingency built into even that if you say that 6% because we've got robust restructuring. With the $125 million increase in pension income, we'll get $125 million more in restructuring as well. And don't forget, when you study our EPS walk, you'll see that the restructuring this year doesn't go away. So the contemplation is that what we would've funded this year, the $100-plus million, will also be in place next year. So you have a very robust pipeline of restructuring as well that we can work with, again, in the case that sales don't materialize to where what we thought. So we feel comfortable with it. I mean, if the world falls apart, that's a different story. But in this environment, if it kind of stays -- if our markets that we serve stay sort of in the state that they're in today and we feel very comfortable with the amount of contingency that we have.

---

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
A lot of ground covered. Just a couple of quick things from me. Just back to aerospares and aftermarket in general, Tom. Have you guys -- I mean, obviously the forecast of kind of trimming your sales a little bit so to speak on growth there relative to industry trends to reflect parts harvesting and inventory collaboration and the like makes a heck of a lot of sense. But I'm wondering if you've actually been able to quantify that. Is this kind of a plausible gut estimate on where this stuff is at? Or have you really been able to kind of demographically work through the fleets and what's been retired and what might be harvested? And where these airlines are in the process of kind of paring inventory and sharing inventory?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, I mean, certainly, all those factors are considered when we arrive at our growth rates. I mean, we, of course, consider North America is the most efficient when it comes to airline efficiency. But the high-growth regions, whether it's India, China or wherever, are trying to pattern themselves after what you see in North America. So those management techniques around spare parts, around aircraft turnaround time, around inventory levels, certainly finding their way to those other markets. We're prepared with it, we're dealing with it and our growth rates do contemplate that.

---

【質問: Jeffrey Sprague (Analysts)】
And then just one other one just to get totally baselined on UOP. So how much has UOP been down for 2015? And typically, how much of your forward -- your sales are kind of backlog-dependent versus kind of licensing and other kind of flow things that might happen over the course of the year?

---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
Yes, so from a revenue perspective, UOP for '15 will be down mid-single digits, and that's going to be comparable for 2016 is the way I'd say it. And then when you think about the different elements of UOP, I'd say the catalysts we do expect to continue over the course of the year. It's a very lumpy business, so you -- maybe you won't see it in the first quarter. But we think catalysts that are at sort of a record level now will kind of stay at that level. So you won't see significant growth there, but we'll continue to see some equipment declines across the portfolio and overall that low single-digit decline or mid-single-digit decline.

---

A couple of cleanup questions. So.
[Technical Difficulty]

【質問: Deane Dray (Analysts)】
You hear me now?

Yes.

---

Sorry about that. Just on the topic of restructuring plans for the year and we know it's being offset with pension, but what would be the cadence of the restructuring actions for the quarters? ---

【回答: Thomas Szlosek (Executives)】
I can't -- I wouldn't rule that out, Dean, but I wouldn't say that that's probably a likely outcome. In fact, the returns on the projects, if you look through them, whether it's the Catalysts projects in UOP or you look at the Fluorine Projects to add the production for mobile air-conditioning and the like, the returns on those are very, very attractive, like north of 30%. I would say that our working capital is adversely impacted by the declines in backlogs that we have in our long-cycle businesses. A lot of those backlogs come with advances. I'm not trying to say there's more opportunity, but I think when you benchmark it we've done really well. But a lot of opportunities I've said, particularly, in our most inefficient business when it comes to the industry and the supply chain in aero and we are really hard at work trying to make some differences there. ---

【回答: Mark Macaluso (Executives)】
Thanks, Alicia. This concludes our outlook call. As always, we're available throughout the day for any follow-up. So thank you, and have a wonderful holiday season.

2026361.transcript_text1:
Good morning, and welcome to our 2016 outlook call. Joining me this morning from the U.S. is Dan Amos, Chairman and CEO; Kriss Cloninger, President of Aflac Incorporated; Fred Crawford, Executive Vice President and CFO of Aflac Incorporated; Teresa White, President of Aflac U.S.; and Eric Kirsch, Executive Vice President and Global Chief Investment Officer. Also from Tokyo joining us today is Paul Amos, President of Aflac; Hiroshi Yamauchi, President and COO of Aflac Japan.
Before we start, let me remind you that some statements in this teleconference are forward-looking within the meaning of federal securities laws. Although we believe these statements are reasonable, we can give no assurance that they will prove to be accurate because they're prospective in nature. Actual results could differ materially from those we discuss today. We encourage you to look at these quarterly earnings releases from some of our -- for some of the various risk factors that can materially impact our results.
Now I'll turn the program over to Dan, who will begin this morning with some high-level comments and outlines of the company's strategic vision; then Paul will provide the strategic focus for our Japan operations and outlook; Teresa will give an update on the U.S. strategy and focus; and Fred will follow up with comments about our capital management strategy and financial outlook; and then Dan will follow up at the end. Dan?

---

Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Many of you probably heard me speak about the importance of the promises that we make to our policyholders and being there when they need us most. Today, we're going to share with you our outlook for 2016. But before we do that, I'd like to share Aflac's strategic vision: to offer higher-quality voluntary products, solutions and services through diverse distribution outlets. In doing so, we are ultimately building upon our market-leading position to drive long-term shareholder value.
At Aflac, we've always managed our business for the long term while maintaining a sharp focus on the financial objectives. At the same time, we continue to work on enhancing our customer service and building our book of business. In doing so, we successfully established strategic points of leverage in both Japan and the United States that we will use to grow and drive shareholder value.
Our industry-leading market share and scale in both Japan and the United States drive our administrative efficiencies. This allows us to offer affordable and value coverage to our customers and competitive compensation to our distributors. At the same time, it drives value for our shareholders. Leveraging our leading position in both countries will help position us for growth going forward.
As product innovators, we've experienced a tremendous amount of success in leveraging the strength of Aflac's recognition and powerful brand to drive sales. About 9 out of 10 people in both countries recognize the Aflac brand. Our brand is a combination of many elements, with the most visible being the Aflac Duck. But it's also made up of trust that we build through relationships with businesses, the policyholders and consumers. In Japan and the U.S., Aflac's established brand has served as an effective door opener. In turn, this serves as a catalyst for customers to be more receptive to hearing how Aflac's products can help them. As just one example, in the United States, One Day Pay, our industry-leading claims initiative, allows us to process, approve and pay eligible claims in just 1 day. Our policyholders and consumers continue to tell us how our commitment to paying claims fast through One Day Pay underscores Aflac's integrity and commitment to delivering on our promise.
Having diverse and productive distribution channels is a strategic point of leverage and a vital component of our growth strategy in Japan and in the United States. As such, this is one area that we focus a great deal of our efforts. Our goal is to have a presence in all outlets where consumers in both countries want to make their insurance purchasing [ph] decisions. We offer innovative products and high-quality customized service to provide businesses and their employees with solutions that protect financial well-being.
We've established a strong capital position with stable earnings and cash flow. Our capital ratios demonstrate our commitment to maintain strong capital levels and flexibility on behalf of our policyholders, bondholders and shareholders. We also regularly assess our capital adequacy to ensure we maintain strong, even under economic scenarios.
Now let me turn the program over to Paul, who will talk about Aflac Japan. Paul?

---

Thank you, Dan. Japan faces the unprecedented challenges of keeping its economy running against the backdrop of social change and reform. As you are aware, the Japanese economy has recently dipped into a technical recession. At the same time, Japan's government is under increasing financial strain to support a growing number of retirees. Given Japan's aging population, declining birth rate and rising medical treatment cost, their health care system has been under increasing financial pressure. These factors present an opportunity. As health-related expenditures continue to grow, so does the need for insurance across all ages, especially the type of products we offer, insurance for daily living. We believe Aflac's products are more vital than ever before, and we are committed to being there for our policyholders in their time of need.
Another factor of social change in Japan relates to womenomics or the increased participation of women in the workforce. Womenomics represents the primary way the government is attempting to address challenges of a shrinking workforce. At Aflac Japan, diversity management is an integrable part of our overall management strategy. For example, last year, we implemented a comprehensive leadership initiative called the women's empowerment program, and we are working to raise the percentage of leadership positions held by women. Research from various sources, including McKinsey consulting, has proven that diverse organizations deliver better financial results, which will impact both Japan's economy and continue to help Aflac Japan.
Turning to the third sector market. With many insurance companies seeing growth opportunities, the landscape remains competitive. While the number of competitors has decreased, medical product competitiveness is on the rise with an increasing variety of products that have shorter life cycles. At the same time, the ongoing low interest rate environment has created changes in the first sector marketplace. Amid this evolving market environment, Aflac is determined to maintain and further expand its position as the leading insurance company in Japan's third sector market by providing solutions for our policyholders as they face a heavy financial burden related to health care cost. In 2015, Aflac Japan significantly expanded its third sector product sales and distribution. Notably, we've strengthened our relationship with Japan Post Holdings.
With respect to third sector products, you will recall at the end of 2014, Aflac Japan introduced the latest version through our cancer product line, New Cancer DAYS, and its strong momentum continued into 2015 across all distribution channels. Then in June 2015, we enhanced our EVER medical insurance with the introduction of riders related to critical illnesses. As we have experienced in the past, the launch of these 2 significant products served to boost sales in 2015. We anticipate that in 2016, the new product schedule will focus on product refinements, including the potential to enter a new area of the third sector market.
In terms of first sector products, the market is further segmented as the level-premium protection oriented products are largely sold in traditional channels and lump sum savings-oriented products are popular in the bank channel. We are refining our approach and will concentrate on level-premium products for cross-selling and stability of returns. The goal is to split the sector into those products that we want to sell based on their characteristics, profitability and limited capital strain. The low interest rate environment has impacted our view on selling first sector products. And the action we took in 2012 in terms of limiting the sale of WAYS, for instance, was the right path for us to take. Going forward, we believe the sale of level-premium products not only enhances the sale of third sector products through cross-selling, but importantly, the product profitability of a level-premium product is more stable, with returns that exceed our cost of capital and benefit from the cross-sell of higher-return third sector products.
Given the very strong sales growth in the first 9 months and our expectation for the remainder of the year, we now anticipate that 2015 sales growth for third sector products will be at the high end of the 10% to 13% range. The successful launch of 2 products in the cancer and health lines creates difficult 2015 sales comparison. As such, we anticipate third sector sales in 2016 will be down mid-single digit. While these results from 2015 create a tough comparison, we are looking to drive a compound annual growth rate for third sector product in the range of 4% to 6% over the long term. We believe that a continued revision and expansion of our third sector product line will aid in achieving this objective.
With respect to first sector sales, 2016 will be a year of transition, making specific guidance more challenging. We expect our proactive approach will drive lump sum product sales down considerably, while level-premium product will essentially track third sector sales down modestly during the year. Recognizing we have an Aflac policy in 1 out of 4 households in Japan, we pay careful attention to the social change and have a track record of developing products and solutions to meet the evolving need of our customers.
Thank you, and now let me turn it over to Teresa White, who will be covering Aflac U.S.

---

Thank you, Paul. I'd like to begin by sharing some highlights of what we're observing in the U.S. market, much of which has been impacted by the Affordable Care Act, or ACA. We continue to see employers opt for high-deductible health plans to reduce expenses associated with offering employee benefit. Although small employers, meaning those fewer than 50 employees, are not required to offer major medical, they continue to look for ways to assist their employees with health coverage. In addition, mid to large employers are still overwhelmed by the regulatory aspects of ACA. These employers are seeking ways to make coverage affordable while, at the same time, reduce the administrative burden of the regulations. Nevertheless, workers continue to look to employers for health care solutions, especially since 52% of U.S. workers can't even afford $1,000 in out-of-pocket expenses. This dynamic has caused many brokers to look to voluntary to help their clients fill gaps brought by a high-deductible health plan.
From a competitive standpoint, the U.S. market remains very dynamic and has been subject to continual change. Group players are entering the voluntary market by either shifting some of their employer-paid offerings to voluntary or creating voluntary products of their own. The ACA has introduced new rules and greater complexity, especially in HR processes, which have led to an increased administrative burden to the employer. In response, this has prompted a renewed focus on technology to help with decision support, HR benefits enrollment, and to help employees to navigate the complex health care system. This environment creates additional opportunities for Aflac, which leads me to our strategic playbook for 2016.
Now as a backdrop, our goal in 2015 was to build out our 2-channel distribution model more specifically by clarifying roles within each channel. Historically, these channels have competed, which created channel conflict. To manage this, we've leveraged the strength of each channel. We've been focusing our career agents on the smaller employers since they typically enjoy the most success by serving employers with less than 50 employees. Here, we're using everwell to drive growth, and I'll talk a little bit more about this in a few minutes. For the mid- to large-case market, we're attracting more brokers than ever before. In fact, the strong performance in many of our successful market operations is due in part to increased collaboration between brokers and career agents. We've made great strides and now have one of the more dynamic value-add distribution models in the industry, which gives us the potential to be unstoppable.
Looking to 2016, we'll continue to focus on enhancing the productivity of our sales distribution. The Affordable Care Act has opened up 2 opportunities for Aflac to fill gaps created by the high-deductible health plans: first, gaps in ACA coverage have allowed us to position Aflac products alongside major medical as a holistic solution; and everwell allows our agents to take a consultative approach to offer this comprehensive solution of major medical and voluntary products to the small-case market. Therefore, we'll continue to focus on recruiting career agents, training them and promoting the use of everwell to support growth in this segment. In addition, as more brokers have entered the voluntary market, we continue to deepen existing relationships with our broker partners who serve the mid- to large-case segment by providing tools and services to support broker needs, such as proposal management tools, improved underwriting systems and enrollment integration.
As Dan mentioned, One Day Pay will continue to be a key differentiator for us, especially as some of the major medical players have entered the voluntary market. Despite these new entrants, we believe One Day Pay, our industry-leading claim initiative, stands out to consumers because it gets cash in the hands of those consumers when they need it the most. We'll continue to promote One Day Pay to the consumer as we feel that this will help drive increased brand loyalty and account penetration.
Lastly, as the voluntary market continues to grow, with the broker channel group products growing at a faster rate, scale and efficiency will become increasingly important. Although we have made some investments in our platform to support our broker partners, we need to make additional technology investments to support continued growth while enhancing persistency and efficiency of the business.
Looking ahead, keep in mind that as our production through brokers grow, we anticipate sales will be increasingly concentrated in the fourth quarter, more specifically the last 4 weeks of the year. In addition, this is the first full year in which the broker sales forecasting model has been in play. We continue to believe that we're on track to meet the lower end of the 3% to 7% range in the U.S. in 2015, and we're assuming that all of the enrollments that are expected will proceed as planned at the end of the year. Now as we look to 2016, we believe sales will increase in the range of 3% to 7%. The voluntary work-site market is currently projected to grow at 5% over the next 3 years. And as you know, we won't be satisfied until we're growing at or above industry rate.
Thank you. And now let me turn the call over to Fred.

---

Thank you, Teresa. Let me start with a few of the key areas we are focused on in terms of financial management as we enter 2016. We continue to execute on our general account investment strategy, expanding into new asset classes and mandating external managers where we lack the expertise. In terms of core asset classes, we added middle market loans over the last year and are in the process of building out a commercial loan portfolio, and we'll initiate a modest investment in equities in the next few weeks. Additionally, in the coming years, we will take a measured approach to adding growth assets, which include public and private equity, hedge funds and other alterative asset classes that are both consistent with our liability structure and industry practices. This is a slow ramp-up, with growth in assets expected to reach roughly $3 billion in 2017. We expect these new asset classes will add significant excess investment income in the long term, recognizing we will incur near-term expenses during the building process.
In terms of risk management, we are working to reduce potential volatility in Aflac Japan's regulatory solvency margin ratio, or SMR, which is sensitive to interest rates, spreads and exchange rates. Reducing volatility allows for greater clarity in identifying excess capital, improves consistency in free cash flow generation, and ultimately drives a lower risk profile in cost of capital.
Measuring our excess capital position includes a block-by-block assessment of the regulatory reserves in Japan and associated reinsurance capacity, testing regulatory capital measures under stress conditions and comprehensive economic capital analysis. We have successfully used reinsurance in the past to unlock excess capital in Japan. We also believe excess capital exists in the U.S. when considering stability and low-risk profile of our business model.
Importantly, we do not see any change in our core principles surrounding risk and capital management. In accordance with our risk appetite, we will maintain strong SMR and RBC ratios at a minimum range of 500% to 600%, leverage at or below 24% and hold roughly $500 million in excess capital and liquidity at the holding company at all times. The plug-in [ph] priorities include supporting our dividend growth track record and a bias towards repurchasing our stock absent compelling alternatives.
Turning to Slide 17 and a discussion of assumptions underlying our 2016 earnings drivers. We expect stability in our core margins. Consistent with comments on our third quarter earnings call, we expect premium growth rates in the low single digits, supported by stable persistency in our sales outlook. Note that Japan premium is somewhat impacted by the combination of reinsurance, the effect of limited pay products reaching paid-up status, and steady decline in first sector sales as we further refine our strategy. I would note that while limited pay product is a headwind to premium growth, it has no impact on profitability as we release deferred profit liability into earnings.
Net investment income primarily in Japan is expected to decline by roughly 1% to 2% in 2016, as a result of calls and maturities of private placement holdings. New money will be reinvested according to our strategic asset allocation, though at lower rates due to lower market yields but arguably will reinforce our strategy of having a more diverse and higher-quality portfolio as we remain cautious on the go-forward credit environment.
We expect core benefit ratios to remain stable and consistent with our generally favorable experience thus far in 2015, and relative to our forecasted long-term ranges discussed at our May financial analyst briefing. In Japan, we anticipate continued strong claims trends in our cancer block in particular. In the U.S., expense ratios are up modestly as a result of investment in overall IT group administration and everwell platforms.
Turning to Slide 18. We expect overall capital conditions to remain stable but are keeping an eye on credit conditions. We are seeing the early signs of a credit cycle with spreads widening in recent months and downgrades modestly outpacing upgrades. We expect to maintain our SMR and RBC ratios in the mid- to high 800% range subject to market values changes. Our SMR ratio is sensitive to rates and spreads, with a roughly 220 point volatility provision that recognizes the unrealized gains in our AFS portfolio and the potential for stress conditions. Leverage will remain in the 23% to 25% range, and we expect to pre-fund approximately $1 billion of maturities prior to coming due later in the year and early in 2017.
We have revised our plans for repatriation in 2015 and now expect to repatriate an additional JPY 60 billion this month, which represents the remaining capital released from our 2015 reinsurance transaction. The December repatriation and associated statutory dividends for the holding company support our $1.4 billion of targeted repurchase for 2016, front-end loading roughly $1 billion of our repurchase in the first half of the year. Note that our 2016 repatriation estimate does not currently assume any reinsurance and represents a stable repatriation of after-tax FSA earnings.
We have reviewed in detail our 2016 and 3-year excess capital position and remain comfortable with a deployable capital range of $6.3 billion to $7.5 billion through 2017. The lower end of the range consistent with our organic free cash flow and the range itself representing additional deployable capital, we believe, is embedded in our Japan and U.S. businesses.
Finally, I'll close with my comments on specific EPS outlook and a few thoughts on driving long-term valuation. We expect stable growth in EPS in the 3% to 7% range, excluding the impact of currency movement. As a basis for our growth rate estimate, for 2015, we assume the midpoint of our $1.36 to $1.56 EPS range for the fourth quarter and normalized for a net $0.05 of positive items called out in our earnings releases during the year. We provide specific EPS guidance and sensitivities to the yen, which remains largely consistent with our third quarter disclosures. We estimate that every JPY 1 move on the annual average exchange rate will equal an approximately $0.025 per share impact on next year's earnings.
ROE is expected to remain in the 18% to 21% range, excluding the impact of currency. Our cost of capital is among the lowest in the industry, benefiting from low exposure to more volatile and capital-intensive equity market and interest-rate-sensitive retirement businesses, transparent profit margins and generating yen cash flows, which allows us to borrow in yen at very low rates. In addition, we believe our work in recent years to reduce concentrated and potentially volatile exposures in the general account have also contributed.
Our financial playbook for creating value is straightforward: defend attractive margins in our core supplemental health businesses; in Japan, allocate capital away from more volatile return and capital-intensive businesses to stable businesses that earn comfortably above our cost of capital; invest to improve service and efficiency in our fast-growing U.S. brokerage and group business; manage the risk in our investment portfolio and associated SMR volatility; and finally, identify idle or excess capital for future deployment at higher rates of excess return while returning back to shareholders.
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Dan for some closing comments.

---

Thank you, Fred. I will close with some thoughts that should be top of mind as we look to next year. Everything that you've heard today is designed around growing our franchise, protecting policyholders and ultimately driving shareholder value.
In Japan and the United States we dominate our markets, and we plan to keep it that way. Aflac Japan, the leading provider of third sector products, will be focused on new product innovation in the third sector market. While we expect sales of first sector products to decline in 2016, those first sector products we do sell will encourage the cross-selling of third sector products. Aflac U.S. is concentrating on leveraging our brand to fuel our growth and benefit our distribution channels while investing to enhance customer experience and efficiencies.
To follow up on Fred's comments, our goal is to achieve stable EPS growth while also investing in the business to drive future growth. When it comes to dividend increases, we belong to an elite club. This year marked the 33rd year of increasing our cash dividend. In addition, by the end of 2015, we expect to have repurchased $1.3 billion of common stock and planned for a modest increase in 2016, absent more compelling opportunities.
I want to reiterate what we said at the financial analyst briefing in May: we still believe there's an opportunity to deploy approximately $6.3 billion to $7.5 billion of capital when looking at a 3-year period ending 2017. We will continue to evaluate all options when it comes to deploying capital and growing the business, but as in the past, we remain disciplined. You've already heard me say that my job is to balance the interest of all stakeholders. I think we did a good job of that this year just as we did in the past, and I believe we're going to do it again next year by delivering on our promises to our policyholders and ultimately enhancing shareholder value.
Now I'll turn the program back over to Robin. Robin?

---

Thank you, Dan. Now we're ready to take your questions. [Operator Instructions] All right, we're ready to go. We'll take the first question, please.

That engine now, even as we look forward to 2016, is now approaching a $75 billion to as high as $80 billion (sic) [ JPY 75 billion to as high as JPY 80 billion ] distribution engine, and that's going to serve to help grow third sector premium. Earned premium in and around the 1.5% to 2% range would be my estimate. When you look at first sector, however, you've got a couple of things going on. One, naturally, you're going to see premium come down because as Paul has outlined, we're refining our approach to it, moving away from lump sum. But the other thing you have going on is you also have some of the more limited pay product. If you recall back to this year's FAB Meeting, we have limited pay product. When it reaches paid-up status, you'll see a more drop-off in the premium levels. And in fact, moving from 2015 to '16, we're seeing about JPY 30 billion of drop-off just related to the paid-up status of this limited premium pay product. Now again, remember, that doesn't impact profitability because we have a liability that we release into earnings, which keeps profitability constant, but it does pressure premium. So when you think of the combination of reinsurance, which is now tailing off, we had reinsurance effect this year compared to next year probably around JPY 5 billion or so of depressed growth related to reinsurance. If you look at that plus the first sector, plus the limited pay product now starting to reach paid-up status, all of those things are contributing to a muted premium growth rate in Japan.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
And Fred, if you just -- following you on that math with the JPY 30 billion drop-off, are we getting like a point or 2 of a decline in premium revenue? Was that directionally close?

【回答: Frederick Crawford (Executives)】
Yes. If you just isolate first sector business, which runs about JPY 0.5 billion a year in earned premium, that -- just that paid-up status is contributing to roughly a 1% decline year-over-year in the earned premium. That's for '16.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
Got it. And you said third sector is supposed to grown 1.5% to 2%. So is it fair to say that you'd still get -- you get kind of flattish to maybe modest growth overall then?

【回答: Frederick Crawford (Executives)】
Well, as I said in my comments, we're expecting about 1% growth in premium overall.

---

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
1% growth, got it, okay. That's helpful color. I appreciate it. And then just my follow-up is, on the -- in terms of the product shift, moving away from lump sum sales in first sector, can you all remind us what percent of Japanese sales this year in first sector were lump sum versus level pay?

---

【回答: Frederick Crawford (Executives)】
I don't have that handy. I don't know if any -- if -- Paul, if you happen to have that handy or not?

---

【回答: Paul Amos (Executives)】
We're looking for it right here, just 1 second.

---

【回答: Frederick Crawford (Executives)】
I'm thinking roughly 1/3.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
1/3 would have been lump sum? Or 1/3 would have been level pay?

【回答: Frederick Crawford (Executives)】
1/3 lump sum.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
1/3 lump sum, got it.

【回答: Robin Wilkey (Executives)】
And if we need to correct that, Tom, we'll do that. We'll look at it and verify that.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
Okay.

【回答: Paul Amos (Executives)】
Really quickly, just looking in our projections, just to verify, it's about half and half. It's split almost down the middle on premium, on an AP basis.

【質問: Thomas Gallagher (Analysts)】
And -- Paul, and that roughly half of the first sector sales, is that going to go to 0? Is that -- or is that just a substantial decline but you'll still have some level of lump sum sales?

【回答: Paul Amos (Executives)】
We are going to have some for a couple of different reasons, Tom. First of all, as I mentioned earlier, when Eric asked, we're going to continue to allow our exclusive agencies to offer that lump sum product because they have to have it in order to be competitive, but we are going to significantly change certain rate in order to make that happen. At the same time, we also have commitments to the bank channel, and those commitments tend to last 6 months at a time. And so we'll continue to see that happen through the first quarter of next year because as you know, the Japan fiscal calendar begins April 1. And so we'll probably see a slower tapering in the first quarter with a faster tapering beyond the first quarter.

---

【質問: Suneet Kamath (Analysts)】
A question on Japan sales and the long-term target of 4% to 6% for the third sector. It just seems like in recent years, we've been experiencing really strong growth in a particular year when you've had a new product introduction and then when you faced comps that were difficult in the subsequent year, had less robust sales growth. So I guess my question is, as we think about this 4% to 6% long-term guidance and the shortening product cycle that the industry is experiencing, Paul, do you think that we can get to a point where you're generating 4% to 6% third sector sales growth on a consistent basis?

---

【回答: Paul Amos (Executives)】
That would certainly be the ideal situation. That said, certain products are going to have a higher level of attractiveness than others. The reaction to our cancer plan exceeded all of our expectations, and we certainly want to take that premium and offer those products that exceeded our total sales number. What I would tell you is that one of the reasons we'd like to enter an additional product line in the third sector is we'd like to see our vision on an annual basis on a 3-year cycle. And so if we add 3 core products in third sector with 1 product revision every year, that would put a -- hopefully, a smoother number for us in attempting to achieve that CAGR. That said, it's very difficult to predict market receptiveness, but that is the objective. As I said, part of the reason this year that we not only face difficult comps but in trying to launch a brand new product in an industry and in -- with a sales distribution that tends to be slower to adapt new products as opposed to new product revisions, we're just trying to be mindful of that as we head into 2016 and think that we can prepare ourselves better for the longer term in achieving that CAGR.

【回答: Daniel Amos (Executives)】
I want to say something. Suneet, this is Dan. In the old days, I would have had a contest that started in the first quarter to shift some of the business from the fourth quarter to the first quarter to try to level it out. It was a conference call that we had with all of you, where everyone said, "Get the business when you can, as quick as you can." And so we shifted back to getting the business as fast and as quick as we can. And we felt like it's better to have the 13% now than if we'd ended up with 6% and 5%, so -- or whatever those totals might be to sum up. But ultimately, we were just trying to get it in. So we could have made it more level by shifting the context, not literally holding business, but just shifting things. So it is our outstanding production in the fourth quarter that's causing our problem for 2016. And so I just want to be clear on that.

It's appreciated. One quick follow-up on Japan. I know you can't give us any specifics about Japan Post, and I appreciate that. But if I go back, Dan, to the relationship that you had with Dai-ichi years ago when you first started it, my recollection is that sales growth was quite strong in that first year and then the relationship became somewhat of a drag on growth in subsequent years because even though you were generating new business, it wasn't quite at the level of that extremely strong first year. So I guess my question is directionally, should we think that Japan Post will be any different from that situation that you experienced?

【回答: Daniel Amos (Executives)】
And the reason you should is with Dai-ichi Life, we hit it all at once. It's been rolled out and -- Japan Post has been rolled out by over a period of years, not just one quick shot. Will it eventually slow down? Probably so unless we come up with something else, new, innovative that we can get together with them on. But let me just say that I give our relationship with Japan Post from what I thought it would be to where it is today, an A. And that's all I can say about that. But I think Aflac Japan and the leadership that Paul and Yamauchi, the sales force, all the people, get an A on what's been going on. And our relationship is stronger today with Japan Post than it has ever been, and I look for it continuing to be strong because it's helping not only us, but it's helping Japan Post and it's helping the policyholders in Japan.

Thank you very much for joining us this morning. If you want to follow up with any information or any calls, please contact us in Investor Relations and we'll be glad to take your call. And again, thank you for joining us this morning. Bye-bye.
