BP9DL90.transcript_text3:
Just had a question or questions on currency, please. I just wondered if you could comment on what you now estimate the currency impact on sales will be for the full year. And just again on currency, we have seen some fall in prices in markets like Mexico, closer to those in Spain for the same product. And I understand that that's mainly due to currency, but I wondered if you could also comment on any general sort of price convergence with Spain recently, and whether you expect that to continue into next year.

---

Well, thank you. About the first part of your question. Well, as you can imagine, we are not updating on a weekly basis everything which has to do with currencies because they are, all the time, moving and we prefer to focus much more on the execution of our business, managing our company and our like-for-like sales growth. Having said that, we are not changing what we transmitted in the month of September in the first half year results. For the full year, we are expecting something around a 0.5% positive currency impact on sales. And regarding the second part of your question. You know that -- the first thing I would like to say is that, of course, our like-for-like sales growth is volume driven, as it is always the case. And regarding prices in the different markets, we always take a long-term approach. What we can say is that currently, our price structure all across the world is flatter than ever. So the price harmonization is more than it has been ever, but the most relevant thing is that like-for-like sales growth is volume driven.

---

Just looking at your like-for-like, which just it's nicely outperforming the majority of the competition. What do you think the key drivers are of that like-for-like at present? Is it just a very strong fashion collection? Do you think you're benefiting from some sort of Euro tourism? Is there anything that you can sort of add to why this -- why you're performing so strongly at the like-for-like level?

---

Yes. Thank you, Rebecca. I would say a combination of everything. Of course, it has to do with the collections; of course, it has to do with this fully integrated approach between stores and online; of course, it has to do with the way we operate the stores, with the refurbishments, the enlargements that we are developing; RFID. So it's a combination of a lot of things, and it's the execution of the business model. This is what summarizes everything; the execution of the business model. We are achieving positive like-for-like in the different geographies. And it's a combination of all the different elements which are involved in the management of the company.

---

Lovely. And are you seeing an acceleration in terms of the like-for-like contribution from the online? I know that it's fully integrated, but clearly, the online allows you to extend your reach to new pockets of customers.

---

Well, what we can say is that we believe very much, as we always say, in this fully integrated approach between stores and online. Of course, online sales are growing. Online, for us, is relevant from 2 different points of view: one has to do with online sales; but the other one, as we have always mentioned, has to do with several million people every day seeing our apps, seeing our webpages, seeing the products. Some of them buying online, some of them buying in the stores. Fully integrated approach, in-store deliveries, in-store returns with the possibility to order online from the stores. So we believe very much in this fully integrated approach, and this is part of it -- of this like-for-like sales growth. But the way to summarize -- because there is not this impact or that impact on the other impact, is the execution of the business model.

---

Following up on Rebecca's question. Do you think the introduction of special prices at Zara, and also a wider range of product on the website, has helped to drive the like-for-like sales growth?

---

I couldn't try to find this or that reason. I come back to what I was saying before. When you have this strong like-for-like sales growth all across the different geographies and in a 9-month period, as we were talking about, it has to do with everything. So it is -- I come back to what I was saying before: it's the execution of the business model, the global management of the company.

---

Okay. And do you acknowledge that the range of product has been much expanded on the website?

---

Sorry? I don't understand your question.

---

We've seen a larger range of products on the website. So for example, more dresses compared to last year. Do you acknowledge that, that is the case?

---

No, no, no. Perhaps it has to do with fashion trends. You can see in one season, fashion trends are more for dresses, another season are more for pants, so -- but no, no, no, we are not increasing the range of products globally.

---

I'm not sure I heard you right. You mentioned that CapEx growth might be below space growth. I'm not sure that I heard correctly. And if that is so, is this something for the short term or is this a new trend going forward?

---

Yes, thank you. Well, this is something we already anticipated more or less 1 year ago, that the new trend of the business wants CapEx growth to be below space growth because CapEx is a combination of openings, refurbishments, and then you have logistics and IT. And during the period 2012 to 2014, we went through a very significant period of investments in logistics, in IT. So that is why we were saying that from this year on, so it is for 2015 and it will be for the coming years, CapEx growth will be below space growth. So this is going to be the trend of the business after 3 years, in which we were investing in a very significant way in logistics.

---

Just one on the gross margins. I was wondering in the third quarter, given the pressure there on the gross margin, if you could give a little bit more color, if not quantitatively, certainly qualitatively, in terms of markdowns, mix and currency. And presumably, you're still happy with your typical gross margin outlook, which is minus 50 to plus 50 basis points for the full year. But is there any reason why Q4 should be any better or worse than what you've seen in the third quarter?

---

Well, thank you. You know that we don't like to elaborate on the gross margin on a quarterly basis. We always say that, at least, you need to think about a full-season basis. And what we were anticipating to do in the month of December is that we were expecting a stable gross margin for the full year. What this means, we always say that for us, stable is plus-minus 50 basis points. We always work for the stability of the gross margin. The gross margin is a combination of many different things. Of course, it has to do with fashion trends, with the mix, with markups, markdowns, currencies. And what we were saying from the very beginning of this year is that this year, because of the dollar exchange rate, it -- regarding which, our exposure is relatively limited, too, because we have a certain level of natural hedging. But in any case, we were saying that it was going to be slightly positive in the first half and slightly negative in the second half. And then globally, a stable gross margin for the year, knowing that for us, stable because the gross margin is not mathematics. It has to do -- finally there is a figure, of course, but it has to do with many different things. So globally, we were saying that we were expecting a stable gross margin for the year, knowing that for us, stable means plus-minus 50 basis points. So there is nothing -- this Autumn-Winter season, we are having strong operating performance. And then considering all these elements together but having in mind this currency impact coming from the euro-dollar exchange rate, is why we were saying that we were expecting a slightly negative gross margin, so nothing really new to say compared to what we were seeing in the month of September.

---

Okay. But just to confirm, there's no reason to assume that currency pressure won't continue into the fourth quarter, right -- this year?

---

Well, basically, we work for the stability of the gross margin. I think that, basically, we should expect this confirmation of what we mentioned for the year, a broadly stable gross margin. And this is where we stand.

---

I've got a general question on China, just how you see the outlook there for the next 5 years. Clearly, the last 5 years has been a very strong growth story for you. Are there any signs of slower growth there? I'm thinking particularly of shopping center developments which might affect your rate of growth going forwards?

---

Well, what we can tell you is that, thinking about our company, we'd be -- of course, we are building a strong presence in China. We are having a very positive performance in the Chinese market with this fully integrated approach between stores and online. We continue opening stores in a significant way. And if we think about the next 5 years, our -- we'll continue growing in China. We have no doubts about the market. Fashion appetite is huge in the Chinese market. So we are growing. Our brands are becoming better and better known. We are having access to more and more customers every season, every year. So we continue feeling very optimistic about the evolution of our business in China in the next 5 years.

---

Right, okay. And store numbers, do you think you could open the same number of stores over the next 5 years as you've done in the previous 5?

---

Yes. We will continue opening stores in a significant way in countries such as China. In 1 year or another, there could be a higher or lower number of store openings, because our approach to expansion is -- as anywhere else, it's a combination between high street locations. If you remember recently, we have opened a very prominent store in Shanghai, a very prominent store in Tianjin. We have enlarged a very relevant store in Beijing, in Xidan shopping center. So it's a combination between high street locations and then shopping malls. And then in any particular year, of course, there could be a little bit more, a little bit less shopping malls -- always been very demanding regarding where we go, we're we don't go. So in any case, a significant expansion in the coming years with this combination between store opening and online, this fully integrated approach.

---

My question is about cash. We've seen, obviously, a big jump in the cash balance this year versus last year. And given your comments around CapEx growing slower than space growth, can you just remind us about how the board is thinking about that? And at what point that cash balance starts to be a problem for your return calculation?

---

Well, thank you. You know that we always update about this in the full year results presentation in the month of March. Our general policy remains the same. It's a combination. Our first priority, of course, is to invest in the long-term profitable growth of the company. But as far as we are generating strong cash flows, we combine this with what we consider an attractive and predictable shareholders' remuneration policy. We are increasing significantly the dividend. In fact, in the last 5 years, we have more than doubled the dividend. Our stated policy is a payout ratio of at least 50%. Last year, where the payout ratio was 63%. So this is the stated policy of the company. And then about each particular year, it is after the full-year -- knowing the full-year results and the Board that takes place in the month of March when we elaborate a little bit more and we update about our dividend policy. But the general policy is the one I have transmitted to you, so increasing regularly and progressively, the dividends. And as I was saying to you, we have more than doubled in a 5 years' period

---

A question about the space expansion. Could you tell us how many refurbs and store enlargements you've done this year? It's quite difficult to get a handle from that -- from the slides that you've given us, on exactly whether this is a sort of unusual year for either of those 2. And also, just update us on your guidance for net openings for the full year, please.

---

Well, Warwick, what we can mention is that in terms of openings and -- we are absolutely on track with the guidance we provided to you at the beginning of the year. Obviously, in the presentation, we selected some enlargements which we think are very relevant; is the case of White City in London and other store in Paseo del Borne in Mallorca because these are very, very relevant flagships. And I think that the main -- what we mentioned is -- what I can mention to you is that space growth remains totally on track. And the effort to make our stores more relevant and more prominent is an ongoing one. So there will always be some refurbishments. So everything is on track, and there is very little I can add on that.

---

So your guidance is 320 to 380 net stores, I think. Can you give us an indication where you'll be within that range, given that you've only got another 6 weeks to go?

---

We'll be within the range. This is what I can tell you. So we are very, very confident on the execution of the expansion plan.

---

We have a number of questions received via the webcast platform. The first of which is in what online markets will Zara be launching in 2016?

---

Well, you know that we have built a strong presence in many different online markets. In fact, in 2015, today in Europe, we are present in 22 European markets. And one thing that we are planning to do next year regarding Zara and the other brands is to be -- to launch online in all the European markets in which we are still not present.

---

The second question received on the webcast platform is Stradivarius is launching a men's collection. When will this take place?

---

We are planning to do it in the year 2017. So this is the approach we have. We are preparing the teams. We are beginning to work on the collections and this idea of incorporating men's clothing into Stradivarius is part of our strategy to complete our commercial offer. In fact, it's something that we are doing in many different concepts. For example, Massimo Dutti has launched their personal tailoring offering; or for example, Oysho, with their sports and gym collection that we decided to launch 2 years ago; Zara Home, with a big development of the cosmetics collection. So this is part of a permanent approach in terms of completing our commercial offering with the different concepts.

---

The final question that we received on the webcast platform relates to payment. Are your stores ready to take payment by phone at the cash register in-store?

---

Well, yes. In fact, there are markets where you can pay by mobile at the cash register right now in our stores. This is the case in the United States. This is the case in the U.K. This is the case in Spain. Our idea is to roll out this technology in all the different markets. It's not a big issue; it's quite simple to introduce this possibility of a payment by phone in all our stores in the world. So there is no big issue about that.

---

I can see from looking at the webcast platform, there are no further questions. So I think we'll conclude there. Thank you very much for joining us today, and that concludes the results presentation.

---

Yes, well, thank you very much. And in any case, of course, through our Capital Markets Department, we are ready to answer any additional questions you may have about these results. Thank you very much for joining us today.
